\begin{document}
Chemical shifts and effective relaxation rates for methyl-containing
GB1 residues. For a magnetic field of 21.1356 T, we scale by 226.3188
to transform chemical shifts to Hz for 13C and by 899.8932 to transform
to Hz for 1H

\begin{table}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline 
Residue number & Aminoacid & Atom & Chem. shift/ ppm (Hz)\tabularnewline
\hline 
\hline 
\multirow{4}{*}{6} & \multirow{4}{*}{Leucine} & C$_{D1}$ & 24.389 (5519)\tabularnewline
\cline{3-4} \cline{4-4} 
 &  & C$_{D2}$ & 25.792 (5837)\tabularnewline
\cline{3-4} \cline{4-4} 
 &  & H$_{D1}$ & 0.471 (423)\tabularnewline
\cline{3-4} \cline{4-4} 
 &  & H$_{D2}$ & 0.528 (475)\tabularnewline
\hline 
\multirow{4}{*}{8} & \multirow{4}{*}{Leucine} & C$_{D1}$ & 25.506 (5772)\tabularnewline
\cline{3-4} \cline{4-4} 
 &  & C$_{D2}$ & 25.758 (5829)\tabularnewline
\cline{3-4} \cline{4-4} 
 &  & H$_{D1}$ & 0.697 (627)\tabularnewline
\cline{3-4} \cline{4-4} 
 &  & H$_{D2}$ & 0.707 (636)\tabularnewline
\hline 
\multirow{4}{*}{13} & \multirow{4}{*}{Leucine} & C$_{D1}$ & 25.236 (5711)\tabularnewline
\cline{3-4} \cline{4-4} 
 &  & C$_{D2}$ & 24.002 (5432)\tabularnewline
\cline{3-4} \cline{4-4} 
 &  & H$_{D1}$ & 0.746 (671)\tabularnewline
\cline{3-4} \cline{4-4} 
 &  & H$_{D2}$ & 0.836 (752)\tabularnewline
\hline 
\multirow{4}{*}{22} & \multirow{4}{*}{Valine} & C$_{G1}$ & 19.848 (4491)\tabularnewline
\cline{3-4} \cline{4-4} 
 &  & C$_{G2}$ & 21.014 (4755)\tabularnewline
\cline{3-4} \cline{4-4} 
 &  & H$_{G1}$ & 0.938 (844)\tabularnewline
\cline{3-4} \cline{4-4} 
 &  & H$_{G2}$ & 0.960 (863)\tabularnewline
\hline 
\multirow{4}{*}{30} & \multirow{4}{*}{Valine} & C$_{G1}$ & 20.219 (4575)\tabularnewline
\cline{3-4} \cline{4-4} 
 &  & C$_{G2}$ & 21.624 (4893)\tabularnewline
\cline{3-4} \cline{4-4} 
 &  & H$_{G1}$ & 0.757 (681)\tabularnewline
\cline{3-4} \cline{4-4} 
 &  & H$_{G2}$ & 0.857 (771)\tabularnewline
\hline 
\multirow{4}{*}{40} & \multirow{4}{*}{Valine} & C$_{G1}$ & 21.342 (4830)\tabularnewline
\cline{3-4} \cline{4-4} 
 &  & C$_{G2}$ & 21.652 (4900)\tabularnewline
\cline{3-4} \cline{4-4} 
 &  & H$_{G1}$ & 0.599 (539)\tabularnewline
\cline{3-4} \cline{4-4} 
 &  & H$_{G2}$ & 0.784 (705)\tabularnewline
\hline 
\multirow{4}{*}{55} & \multirow{4}{*}{Valine} & C$_{G1}$ & 20.505 (4640)\tabularnewline
\cline{3-4} \cline{4-4} 
 &  & C$_{G2}$ & 19.665 (4450)\tabularnewline
\cline{3-4} \cline{4-4} 
 &  & H$_{G1}$ & -0.407 (-366)\tabularnewline
\cline{3-4} \cline{4-4} 
 &  & H$_{G2}$ & 0.330 (297)\tabularnewline
\hline 
\multirow{4}{*}{7} & \multirow{4}{*}{Isoleucine} & C$_{G1}$ & 27.143 (6142)\tabularnewline
\cline{3-4} \cline{4-4} 
 &  & C$_{G2}$ & 16.934 (3832)\tabularnewline
\cline{3-4} \cline{4-4} 
 &  & H$_{G1}$ & 0.739 (665)\tabularnewline
\cline{3-4} \cline{4-4} 
 &  & H$_{G2}$ & 0.707 (636)\tabularnewline
\hline 
\end{tabular}

\caption{Chemical shifts and effective relaxation rates for methyl-containing
GB1 residues. For a magnetic field of 21.1356 T, we scale by 226.3188
to transform chemical shifts to Hz for 13C and by 899.8932 to transform
to Hz for 1H}

\end{table}

An additional residue, that produces not so relevant features in the
spectrum.

\hline

\end{tabular}
